description:
Marmota flaviventris, commonly known as the yellow-bellied marmot, is a species of large ground squirrel found in the mountainous regions of western North America. This rodent belongs to the genus Marmota, which are members of the family Sciuridae, or true squirrels.

The yellow-bellied marmot is characterized by its stocky build, short legs, and rounded body shape. Its fur is typically a grizzled brown or gray on the upper parts, with a distinct yellow or orangish-yellow belly and chest. Adults can reach a total length of up to 60 cm (24 inches) and weigh between 3 to 6 kg (6.6 to 13.2 lbs).

These marmots are highly social animals, living in colonies and exhibiting complex communication behaviors. They are known for their distinctive high-pitched whistles, which serve as warning calls to alert the colony of potential predators. Yellow-bellied marmots are primarily herbivorous, feeding on a variety of grasses, forbs, and other vegetation found in their alpine and subalpine habitats.

During the winter months, these marmots enter a state of deep hibernation, where their body temperature, heart rate, and metabolic processes are significantly reduced to conserve energy. This adaptation allows them to survive the harsh environmental conditions of their mountain dwelling.

Marmota flaviventris plays an important role in the ecosystem, serving as a food source for various predators, such as coyotes, foxes, and birds of prey. Their burrowing activities also help to aerate the soil and create microhabitats for other small mammals and invertebrates.
